p: There has been an increasing number of ethnobotanical market surveys in the past decades [ 11]. Although there are a number of studies that compare different markets to each other in terms of availability of plant species [ 12– 14], few studies have repeated ethnobotanical surveys in markets that were already monitored decades before to examine changes in species composition [ 15, 16]. Likewise, few market surveys have included an analysis of vernacular names of medicinal species being sold [ 12, 17]. The availability of plant products at markets changes over time [ 16], indicating the importance of periodically conducting market surveys for a more complete picture of plant availability and to assess possible impacts of social and environmental factors [ 15, 18, 19]. Furthermore, the analysis of vernacular names associated with plant species can inform us more about people’s cultural and botanical history in the study area [ 17].
